When Bardina degei cooks dinner , she does not use a stove .
It even seldom uses a pot .

In its wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of the Paniai Regency in the troubled Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife usually puts a sweet potato - locally called " nota " - directly into the fireplace .
After half an hour the stolen bone is taken from and swallowed with diligent , unwashed hands .
Degei sits on the mud floor - she has no furniture - where she performs her daily work , such as washing clothes with water from the nearby swamp .
A bucket in a single room serves as a rubber ring .
As the youngest of the four wives of her husband , she was not assigned any fields .
Polygamy is common here .
Of course , late work can be dangerous : most of the villagers are unemployed , and many drink hard , and there are soldiers here .
No one dares to walk around in the village after 5 o 'clock  , she says .

It is a rare insight into everyday life in the highlands of Papua , a former Dutch colony , which was taken up in 1969 after a controversial referendum in Indonesia , when only 1,026 elders should vote by means of a public survey of occupying forces .

An existing movement that stirred up the independence of Dutch rule quickly turned against the Jakarta government , which maintains control of the region and excludes foreign journalists or legal observers .
In 2003 , the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua , with the independent part of Papua New Guinea covering the eastern part of the island .
Enarotali is as remote as it is often , with a 90-minute flight from the provincial capital Jayapura to Nabire and a 5-minute car every morning with the rental car .
There is no public transport .
The city , with approximately 19,000 inhabitants , consists of wooden buildings surrounded by bamboo fences and corrugated corrugated roofs .
Very few Indonesians have made their journey here , let alone journalists and virtually no foreigners .
Before Christian missionaries arrived , Mee Pago Papuans called Uga Tamee .
There have been other changes .
We were not accustomed to wearing this clothing  says Degei and points to her vivid , handwoven Turban , her dark shirt and her bright rock .

Papua is the poorest province in Indonesia , where 28 % of people live below the poverty line and some of the worst child mortality and literacy rates in Asia .
But it is also a gold country for Indonesia .

The largest and most profitable gold mine in the world , Grasberg , owned by the Phoenix Freeport McMoran , is just 60 miles from Paniai , a high land province of New Jersey with 153,000 inhabitants .
In 2015 alone , Freeport accounted for $ 3.1 billion in gold and copper .
Moreover , Papua has an estimated $ 78 billion of wood resources .
But these riches are a source of misery for the Papua , ensuring that Indonesia ’ s powerful military retain a suffocating presence .
A 2005 survey in the New York Times reported that Freeport paid almost $ 20 million to local military and units between 1998 and 2004 , including up to $ 150,000 to a single officer .
